File: Shun Wins Yuzubowl.jpg (549 KB, 1578x1832)

>>128159235
But he also gave Yuya his first real defeat that broke Yuya's EGAO. While Yuya lost to Yuzu before, that was when Yuya didn't know what the Pendulums did and the duel itself had no actual consequence or impact. It was just something that was irrelevant in the long run.

Even the Sora vs Shun rematch, while Shun never seemed to care he was almost carded before he could save Ruri, was still relevant. It caused Serena to save Shun and resulted in Serena learning more about the Heartland invasion and herself joining the Lancers.

Whereas when Yuya got BTFO by Reiji, it had a far greater impact since Yuya was forced into the Lancers, suffered his first real loss, and it was Reiji's third duel across 50 episodes.

Though Reiji is quite possibly the WORST STRATEGIST EVER when it came to the Lancers. Then again, Reiji is the guy who thought he could recruit Sora into the Lancers (see episode 26, and less so in episode 35) despite Reiji knowing he is from Academia. Sora being from Academia while not being a counterpart of Yuya/Yuzu basically solidified he wasn't joining the Lancers.

TL;DR: Yuya vs Reiji rematch was a good duel, and Reiji is dumb for trying to recruit a kid drunk on Fusion Dimension nationalism to fight against the Fusion Dimension.

Because nobody cares. Lost Children's plot is completely separate to Conviction's, and Guts doesn't get the conviction (hue) to rescue and protect Casca until a good while after the arc concludes.

>>128161514
>the gradual change of mood of the series doesn't disturb me as much as it does to some people

I think that's because most of Guts' party are likely to stick around for the endgame. None of them (except Serpico, Roderick and maybe Isidro) are instantly likable, so that had to be built up over the course of many years, supplemented by the security that Schierke brings to the jRPG party. This is in contrast to the Band of the Hawk, who were supposedly invincible grim reapers of the battlefield, and mainly likable (except Corkus) from the get-go.

>>128162249 >>128162323 >>128164170
>>128161887
Honestly, I think it would be best if she died. It would create drama and tension between Guts and company, as he would likely blame them for her demise.

Despite the loss, Guts continues on a mission with the group to infiltrate Falconia, who becomes progressively more irritable and unstable. The group begins to fear him more and trust him less, which further exacerbates his already anguished mental state.

Once inside Falconia the hound consumes him completely and the city begins to fall apart as he rips through both apostles and men while a desperate Schierke tries to direct him towards his target (Griffith or whatever).

>>128162724
Almost any monosyllable. E only changes to the Romantic I sound if it is followed by another letter, generally I or E.
Feed, Greed, Mead, Seed, Reid, Keep, Seep
compare
Fed, Red, Med(ical, icine), Led, Tred, Bed, etc.
>>

>>128172064
second last chapter released. when Locus gives Rickert the tour of the apostle gladiator ring.

>>128172067
>How did Mozgus become an apostle?

The egg apostle pricked him with his needle thing while they were holed up in the church by the sludge. Most apostles can do this.

>How did the Egg-Shaped Apostle sacrifice his world?

It was an extra special situation because he had literally nobody else in his life to sacrifice.

>Did God Hand orchestrate Griffith to be reborn through the Egg-Shaped Apostle?

Yes. however it's important to note that they DID NOT intend for the egg apostle to consume casca's child and throw him into the mix.

>Why did the town become consumed by evil?

Most in-universe characters attributed that to having two branded souls in an area with astronomical strife and mountains of dead. But it could just have been godhand trickery.

>>128173663 >>128174514
>>128172116
I don't think we'll ever get their origin story but considering how every final Apostle fight ends with some flashback of their lives, it might be possible.

We can already guess most of their backstories to a certain extent.
Void was the wiseman 1000 years ago who built a cult and then got sent to prison for torture after he became a threat to Skull Knight.
Slan was probably an insanely beautiful woman whom people would kill to sleep with. Plus would commit pegan orgies and whatnot.
Conrad seems like the type of Minister Foss who manipulates and can change people's ideals simply by talking to people. (like he did with Griffith at the Eclipse). I also somewhat think he used plagues and disease to fuck around with other kingdoms.
Ubik is the only one I can't figure out. He seems like a Freud type of person who probably ran a mental asylum and fucked with people's brains and mental state. The issue I have with this is that all other God Hand seem to have been very important people who likely fell from grace just like Griffith. But Ubik doesn't seem that important if he was just in charge of an insane asylum or was just a doctor who fucked around with people.

>>128180637
>>128179475
>>128178798
To simplify something more complex:
In northern Italian dialects when an 's' is between two vowels (such as in 'Farnese') the pronunciation is /z/ (the inverse happenz as well with 'z' becoming /s/). This disappears when going south, but standard Italian is based predominantly on northern dialects.
>>

>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)15:17:42 No.128174108
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)07:17:42 No.128174108 ▶
>>128174158 >>128174222 >>128174719 >>128174749 >>128176533 >>128176732 >>128176753 >>128176850 >>128177081 >>128178942 >>128179057 >>128179177 >>128180225
>>128173963 (OP)
You do not need CCCP or KCP anymore. MPC-HC now comes with LAV Filters installed. All you need is MPC-HC, MadVR and xysubfilter, and you can use ffdshow audio instead of LAV if you like for advanced audio features like virtual surround for headphones, Winamp plugin support, etc.
Set MadVR chroma upscaling to NNEDI3 64 neurons, image upscaling to Jinc, and under remove artifacts, set debanding to high if watching Horriblesubs. Turn on smooth motion. If this shit is too slow switch NNEDI3 to super-xbr, sharpness 100 for chroma upscaling. Doubling/quadrupling luma/chroma resolution with super-xbr or NNEDI3 can help a lot for upscaling if your computer is fast enough.
>>
Anonymous

Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)15:27:31 No.128174492
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)07:27:31 No.128174492 ▶
>>128174552 >>128174590 >>128178893
>>128174420
>What's the point of all the different packs?
There literally is none now that MPC-HC comes with LAV filters pre-installed. MPC-HC will play all of your Chinese cartoons as-is now. You do not need to install anything else at all to watch Chinese cartoons with MPC-HC. xysubfilter is nice, though, for rendering subs at your monitor's native resolution, and MadVR is nice for improving picture quality, especially when upscaling.
>>

07/16/15(Thu)16:35:57 No.128177189

File: [Hiryuu] Dog Days'' - 05 (...).png (1.89 MB, 1280x720)
1.89 MB PNG
Get CCCP.

Get madVR.

Open MPC and set madVR in options -> output.

Play something and go to madVR options.

Disable exclusive fullscreen mode.

Turn on AR filters in upscaling algorithms.

That's literally everything you need for 95% of the possible quality. The remaining 5% is playing around with algorithms and you shouldn't even bother with it unless you have a gaming PC.
>>

07/16/15(Thu)17:08:46 No.128178415
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)09:08:46 No.128178415 ▶
>>128178499
>>128178290
>I get frame dropd
Are you sure? Open up a file and start playback. Hit cntl-J to bring up stats in the upper left. Wait a couple of seconds for shit to stabilize. You WILL see dropped frames counted in the upper left. It always does this when you first start a file. Once playback has stabilized, do you see the dropped frames counter continuing to increase? If so, use less demanding settings. If not, you're good. Also, smooth motion shouldn't have that drastic of an impact unless you're on a toaster or already using demanding upscaling like NNEDI3.
>>

I prefer not to have any dropped frames past those first few seconds. Smooth motion certainly isn't as important as the upscaling options anyways, so sure, leave it off. By the way, you may not realize this, but MadVR is always chroma upscaling, even if you're watching a 1080p file on a 1080p monitor, as Chinese cartoons these days tend to store the chroma information in a lower resolution.

07/16/15(Thu)17:22:02 No.128178893

>>128178796
see
>>128174492
I'd advise a clean MPC-HC and MadVR install minus KCP to prevent future problems from occurring. I personally had a playback problem with CCCP which was fixed when I realized new versions of MPC-HC had LAV filters pre-installed, uninstalled CCCP and installed a clean copy of MPC-HC then added MadVR and xysubfilter to it manually. KCP and CCCP are unnecessary bloatware which can create playback issues.
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)17:22:29 No.128178911

File: shrugs.png (12 KB, 560x407)
12 KB PNG
>>128174420
>What's the point of it all? Why not make something that just works?

Digital multimedia encoding and playback is a highly complex area of computer science. There's a myriad of combinations possible to playback video, audio, subtitles, etc and not all of them are compatible. Some are better than others and not everyone has the same opinion. That's why you see various codec packs.

>something that just works
Something for the masses you say? Something that doesn't need technical expertise? They created DVDs and Blu-ray for that. You go to the shop, pay for them, get home and plug them into your player and you're set.
>>

Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)17:28:53 No.128179177
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)09:28:53 No.128179177 ▶
>>128179006
>What is the best madVR config for sharpness and image clearness?
There is none. It's source-dependent. >>128174108 is a decent general starting point. You're going to have to learn yourself through trial and error. In general, NNEDI3 > super-xbr > Jinc > Lanczos > anything else, but there will be source-dependent exceptions to this regarding the different upscalers' artifacts and how they handle source defects.
I've found that the LumaSharpen filter under image enhancements and upscaling refinement, when set to its lowest possible strength, default settings otherwise, produces an extremely subtle sharpening effect with no noticeable artifacting with most sources.
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)17:29:02 No.128179182
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)09:29:02 No.128179182 ▶

Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)17:39:43 No.128179572
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)09:39:43 No.128179572 ▶
>>128179683 >>128180096
>>128179459
>What sharpening options do you use?
Highly source-dependent, especially FineSharp, which really shouldn't be used for anything but properly encoded 1080p BD rips. AdaptiveSharpen also produces a fairly strong effect even at its weakest setting, so it's definitely not for all sources. As I noted earlier, LumaSharpen with its strength at minimum can be quite useful due to the lack of artifacting it creates. None of the sharpening options will have much of an effect unless you turn on SuperRes and apply SuperRes first.
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)17:40:30 No.128179600
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)09:40:30 No.128179600 ▶
>>128180096
>>128179459
AdaptiveSharpen 0.3 in image enhancements and 0.6 in upscaling refinement. Also SuperRes 2, 1.00, 2.
>>

>>128179459
>>128179572
Also, if you're upscaling, I'd recommend attempting luma doubling/quadrupling before going to the sharpening options. This will have a less destructive effect on the image while still having a nice sharpening effect.
>>

Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)17:57:56 No.128180296
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)09:57:56 No.128180296 ▶
>>128180096
>Do I apply SuperRes before sharpening or not?
Not him. The sharpening filters work much, much better with apply SuperRes first turned on. BTW, MadVR updates your anime instantly when you hit apply, so, even in fullscreen, you can access MadVR through the right click menu then see the changes in real-time as you click apply in MadVR.
>>

Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)18:03:33 No.128180504
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)10:03:33 No.128180504 ▶
>>128180358
I find it works better to turn SuperRes on, set apply SuperRes first, then start from minimal sharpening settings and increase the sharpening from there until you get noticeable artifacting. I find that this will produce a sharper image than SuperRes last and higher sharpening settings can without noticeable artifacting.
I could be wrong on this and it could be a source-specific thing, but this was the result of my experimentation with this.
>>

「生き血を啜らずとも、自らの血肉を自在に操るくらいでなければ吸血鬼の王とは呼べません。
伯父上のように弱くてはとても」

I don't really understand the 弱くてはとても does it have the same meaning as とても弱くて just backwards? but if thats the case that doesn't make a lot of sense unless shes saying even though shes as weak as her uncle but that doesn't make sense considering the shits shes been doing.

>>128152614

Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)02:40:29 No.128153329
Anonymous 07/16/15(Thu)18:40:29 No.128153329 ▶
>>128153382 >>128153713
>>128153148
If a sentence ends in とても it's usually negative, think of it as とてもありえない with the latter part being implied.
So it's saying that her being as weak as her uncle doesn't make sense.
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)02:42:14 No.128153382
Anonymous 07/16/15(Thu)18:42:14 No.128153382 ▶
>>128153498
>>128153329

>>128153891
To me it looks like they're comparing her to her uncle.
伯父上のように弱くてはとても - (she can control the blood so) Her being as weak as her uncle makes no sense.
For your interpretation to work it would have been
父上のように弱ければとても

>>128154401
>>128154107
>For your interpretation to work it would have been
>父上のように弱ければとても
Why do you think this? Why would you think the grammar would need to change for 出来ない as opposed to ありえない？ You're wrong by the way.

>伯父上のように弱くてはとても - (she can control the blood so) Her being as weak as her uncle makes no sense.
She's the one speaking. Why are you interpretting it as third person? ありえない just doesn't make sense here. 無理 would be okay, but of course that has the same meaning as 出来ない
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)03:14:16 No.128154401
Anonymous 07/16/15(Thu)19:14:16 No.128154401 ▶
>>128154533
>>128154291
>Why would you think the grammar would need to change for 出来ない

Because 弱くては出来ないis not grammatically correct, putting はとても in between won't change that.
無理 would be okay yes, but it's not interchangeable with 出来ない
>>

>>128154604
>>128154401
>Because 弱くては出来ないis not grammatically correct
If it is grammatically incorrect, so is 弱くてはありえない. Neither is grammatically incorrect though. The difference is just that 無理 and 出来ない make sense, and ありえない doesn't.

07/16/15(Thu)04:51:39 No.128156782

>>128156913 >>128156982
So Im new to kanji. I finished Kana, right now im working on vocab/grammar very beginner levels. So I wana know how important are radicals? And If I wanted to learn them. Is sooner the better?
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)04:58:11 No.128156913
Anonymous 07/16/15(Thu)20:58:11 No.128156913 ▶
>>128156782
>So I wana know how important are radicals? And If I wanted to learn them. Is sooner the better?
They're somewhat important. It's between minor and moderate. If you draw a few common kanji according to proper stroke order a few times, you'll get a natural feeling for what a radical/component really is. Some radicals have meanings, but the overwhelming majority don't. If you see a radical several times, in a lot of similar words, it's good to look it up, just in case it means something.
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)05:01:42 No.128156982
Anonymous 07/16/15(Thu)21:01:42 No.128156982 ▶
>>128156782
Blow through RTK as quickly as you can. You will get tired and most likely won't finish but you'll learn enough about radicals that when you eventually revert back to studying kanji like normal Japanese people do, you'll have as much of an understanding about them as you'll need.

Seriously it will become super discouraging after a few times when you've studied kanji for hours and then you realize you still can't read or even coherently tell Japanese people what you studied
>>

07/16/15(Thu)07:48:00 No.128160183

>>128160161
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)07:53:17 No.128160294
Anonymous 07/16/15(Thu)23:53:17 No.128160294 ▶
>>128159963
This is what's worked for me, in no particular order:
- Anki: Core 2k/6k/10k i+1 Optimized, Mined Vocabulary, RTK with RevTK
- Reading: Everything from everywhere including manga, LNs, VNs, videogames esp. JRPGs, wikis, imageboards, JLPT resources, etc. Start with Yotsubato, Ika Musume and work your way up.
- Grammar: TK for the basics, DOJG for the rest, doubts about sentences here. Tried Imabi but it's a bit too wordy in my opinion though referencing some of its in-depth articles is worth it for tricky concepts that aren't in the DOJG.
- Listening: Nihongo Sou Matome series and (Shin) Kanzen Master series for systematized study that goes from easy to hard.
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)07:55:24 No.128160338

Anyway 2 hours right when I get up with a 10 minute break after the first hour and then another 2 later on in the day but not too late sounds good.

I haven't done it myself so I can't say, sorry. But for those studying with textbooks that's the one that comes after Minna 2.
Preview : http://nihongo.9640.jp/sample/9784874244470.pdf
It has two other books too it seems (Kanji / exercises) : http://nihongo.9640.jp/english/books/books-tobira.html

There's also another book named "An Integrated Approach To Intermediate Japanese" you could look into, too.

Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)09:19:10 No.128162266
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)01:19:10 No.128162266 ▶
>>128162370 >>128162582
>>128161836
If you cannot read, take a look on Japanese the manga way. It will refresh your grammar memory and fill holes you got from MNN, if you have them.
This book + Anki core 2000 (make sure to learn how to write every kanji from memory, don't make my mistake) should be enough to start reading LN. VN (eroge at least) will be pretty easy at this level.

I don't care about writing at all (who fucking wants to talk with gooks anyway), but from this base i was able to start having fun with japanese.
>>

I can write every kanji from core 2000 from memory, but I cannot make up sentences japanese.
Basically I can read and understand, but i cannot write myself. I have same shit with my english, but i think you can already see that in my writing anyway.

Writing kanji is the best way to make sure you remember them well enough to not get confused when you meet them "in the wild".
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)09:42:56 No.128162869

Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)09:43:32 No.128162886
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)01:43:32 No.128162886 ▶
>>128163104 >>128164682
>>128162699
They're more interesting than textbooks for me. The Sou Matome and Kanzen Master series are musts if you want to keep doing systematized study after the beginner level, and even then you're not going to find much difficult material (as in complex grammatical structures) in shounen manga, moege, etc. so these ease you into reading more advanced material like plot-driven VNs, novels, etc.
>>

Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)12:08:02 No.128166900
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)04:08:02 No.128166900 ▶
>>128165985
That's your choice. Though I guess they expect you to do all of them in parallel.

The Sou Matome books are structured to be a six week course for each level (N3, N2, N1) with a single lesson a day (the chapter names reflect that). You can of course go at a faster pace if you want to, I did the listening book of N3 in 2-3 days, for example.

The Kanzen Master series is different in structure to the Sou Matome series. First, it's structured by lessons not by days. Second, it's all written in Japanese, no English whatsoever. Third, it's harder than the equivalent Sou Matome series.

You can go through both series as they're both pretty good. You can use Sou Matome as preparation for the Kanzen Master equivalent.
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)12:16:12 No.128167169
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)04:16:12 No.128167169 ▶

07/16/15(Thu)12:29:30 No.128167700

>>128168010 >>128168136
>>128166676
If you're going through the DoJG deck (or using the reference in general), realize that it's mostly to use as reference or to refresh your memory. If you want actual explanations, you're supposed to read the entry in the DoJG as it goes much more in depth. CoRくん himself said that's how the deck is supposed to be used when doing new cards (reading the entire DoJG entry for each new concept as you go along as the notes and explanations are not in the deck or reference page).
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)12:39:03 No.128168010

Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)12:49:36 No.128168354
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)04:49:36 No.128168354 ▶
>>128168136
Yeah, that's what I meant by reading the entry, since the stuff in the grammar reference page is basically just the headers of the entries and some example sentences / sometimes a formation table. There should probably be something somewhere to make that a little more clear.

It's still very useful for finding the entries you're looking for / quickly refreshing your memory on concepts you've already read through (though the deck is there for the latter), but it isn't intended to be a replacement to DoJG; just a large reference/index that includes example sentences and formation tables.
>>

It's because people on mount stupid think doing production is somehow useful for language acquisition when it's been shown in plenty of studies that comprehensive input is really the only variable that determines how much quickly one can acquire language. That is why retards who just start out think knowing the difference is useful, when all that really matters is if you understand and the rest will come with that understanding.

>>128170862
It's much more nuanced than a/the.
Xが好きでYは嫌い
is correct while
Xが好きでYが嫌い
is not. That should be enough to show that you need to think about the whole sentence and can't just use a simple rule.

>>128170884
Okay, so just a red herring.

If you don't see the difference between the two situations you must have an IQ of 80. Nonstandard != advanced. Most dialect stuff is just simple substitutions that work exactly the same way as the comparable thing in standard Japanese.

古文 is more difficult, but if you can't bring up an example in standard, modern Japanese then you should just admit defeat.

Just my 2 cents but it's really common for songs to have random particles at the end of sentences to convey a particular feeling. I can't exactly explain it with word, it's just something I learned how to feel with time. Try to visualize that particule encompassing what's behind it if that helps.
>>

>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)16:28:28 No.128176857
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)08:28:28 No.128176857 ▶
>>128177268
>>128176693
It has more than one meaning. It can sometimes be used just to indicate order or multiple actions
AしてはB
Doing A then B
or
Doing A and B

It can also mean "if"

I can't think of it being used as "in order to"
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)16:29:33 No.128176909
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)08:29:33 No.128176909 ▶
>>128177099 >>128177819
>>128176670
は here means these 2 actions are being done repeatedly, one after the other.
>>

Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)16:38:00 No.128177268
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)08:38:00 No.128177268 ▶
>>128177819
>>128176857
Is there any difference between 愛しき人の面影を探しては、貴方の夢を独り見つめてる and 愛しき人の面影を探して貴方の夢を独り見つめてる?

As I see it, the first one can be translated as:
>In order to search for the traces of your loved ones, follow your dreams alone. (shows order and condition)
>If you want to search for the traces of your loved ones, follow your dreams alone. (shows condition)
>Search for the traces of your loved ones and follow your dreams alone. (shows order)
>>

>>128177268
See >>128176909
Lyrics generally don't make much sense in the first place but I would translate the は version as:
>I keep searching for the traces of my loved one and dreaming about you alone.
Without は:
>I search for the traces of my loved one and dream about you alone.

Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)17:24:03 No.128178981
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)09:24:03 No.128178981 ▶
>>128179221 >>128179969
>>128178610
I was going to link to the text file CoRくん had but he took it down.
Hiragana and katakana, and then do these at the same time:

>Grammar
Pick between Tae Kim, Japanese: The Manga Way, and Genki. They all have their strengths and weaknesses, so just pick what looks the most appealing to you. Solidify the grammar through reading and using the DoJG deck(s) in the mediafire link. Make sure to read the DoJG alongside the deck if you're going to use it. The page numbers are there for a reason.
>Vocabulary
For now just just use the Core 2k/6k deck in the OP resources (in the Anki startup link). You can also get the DoJG vocab deck in the mediafire link if you want to make sure you know all of the DoJG's vocab going into it.
>(optional) Kanji
If you want to do focused study for kanji in order to handwrite or to help with recognition, go through RTK and find a deck to review it with.
>>

07/16/15(Thu)17:30:00 No.128179225

>>128178644
A language is hard based off of what you already know.
For instance, if you knew Spanish, then Italian would be easy but Russian would be hard, or if you knew Korean, then Japanese would be easy but English would be hard, but if you know English, then the only advantage you have when it comes to Japanese is that you can kind of say a few words like hamburger or McDonald's, but for the most part, nothing you know will carry over, so for an English speaker, Japanese is hard as fuck.
>>

Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)17:48:07 No.128179899
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)09:48:07 No.128179899 ▶
>>128179991 >>128180769
>>128179542
>>128179728

This anon >>128179608 Pretty much sums up my experience, except I didn't stop doing new vocab cards when I started RTK. Granted, after the first 2k words in Core it does get easier. 1k kanji in the first 2k words, 800 over the next 4000. Really just involves new combinations and new pronunciations. RTK is still pretty neat depending on how you're reviewing it, though; I've definitely noticed it helps with recognition, since if you review by production (various kanji meanings on front, kanji/stroke order/heisig and koohii stories on back) you're basically getting 100% recall on what components the kanji uses and there's never going to be any you mix up due to a small difference.
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)17:48:49 No.128179922
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)09:48:49 No.128179922 ▶
>>128179991

Don't make your own deck. A few threads ago an anon linked a RTK deck that seemed interesting, I haven't tried it myself but look into it maybe?
http://japaneselevelup.com/japanese-level-up-rtk-mod-anki-deck/ otherwise grab the deck from the anki website.

>>128180173
You're the cancer of djt.
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)17:59:09 No.128180345
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)09:59:09 No.128180345 ▶
>>128180399 >>128180448 >>128180449 >>128180574
>>128180248
Yes, that is how most people do it. If you do RTK you will notice afterwards you will either forget the mnemonic completely for just recognition, or you will try and recall the mnemonic constantly and slow yourself down. The only time the mnemonic is useful is when you are recalling it without seeing, and the only time that is useful is for writing. That is why RTK goes keyword > kanji and not kanji > keyword. It is for remembering the radicals from scratch. It is not worth it if you want to read / type, which is recognition only.
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)17:59:32 No.128180359
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)09:59:32 No.128180359 ▶
>>128180454 >>128180843
>>128180289
We told you, anon. Learning Kanji individually improves vocabulary retention, it's a short-term investment for a long-term reward.
>>

Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)18:09:10 No.128180718
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)10:09:10 No.128180718 ▶
>>128180454
>You forget the mnemonic for recognition in the same way that you would just learn it through recognition in the first place though
Except the part where it's much harder to reach that point with brute force. You don't need to read the introduction, you need to read up on mnemonics. Recognizing the Kanji isn't the only benefit it leaves you either: radicals for searching and distinguishing Kanji, meaning for vocabulary acquisition, stroke order for searching and reading handwriting better.
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)18:09:53 No.128180756
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)10:09:53 No.128180756 ▶

無知乙
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)18:10:05 No.128180767
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)10:10:05 No.128180767 ▶
>>128180544
Consider trying KD. The mnemonics are shit, sure, but it gives you more context, actually useful readings and example vocab words for each kanji, which I found more useful than writing.
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)18:10:06 No.128180769
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)10:10:06 No.128180769 ▶
>>128179899
>>128180289
I decided to give RTK a whirl after about 7000 words of bruteforcing core and my own mined decks.

Like you, I didn't stop reading / learning new vocab, I've only mixed RTK into my daily routine. I'm about halfway through it now and the results have been fucking astounding.

The words in my deck that contain kanji that I haven't covered yet are still constantly lapsing and fucking up as usual. The ones that contain only kanji I have names for, I'm retaining with ease. The difference is crystal clear.

Not only do you not confuse kanji with one another, but you gain a complete mnemonic system to assist with vocab. There is no drawback to it; it's really easy, and it helps a lot. It's pure win.

If you look closely at the anti-RTK faggots, they're usually pummeling a strawman that spends 2 years doing RTK before even learning hiragana, or they're trying to call you retarded because you don't have autistic rain man memory for kanji. Just ignore them.
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)18:11:19 No.128180819
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)10:11:19 No.128180819 ▶
>>128180250
because I can do both
>>
Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)18:11:43 No.128180827

>>128180544
Remember that the Reviewing the Kanji website exists, don't waste time creating your own mnemonics likely made a story better than the one you could've come up with. Also, try to do it fast or in conjunction with grammar.
>>

Anonymous
07/16/15(Thu)18:12:54 No.128180867
Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)10:12:54 No.128180867▶
>>128180718
You get the meaning through the words that they are in. Knowing a word that contains the kanji is worth way more than a single English RTK word, which are often times not perfect because of the way RTK goes out of it's way to not have similar meanings for kanji, etc.The other two things you listed are incredibly irrelevant. You can learn stroke order by itself in like 15 minutes, and looking up kanji accounts for such a small amount of time that it's irrelevant anyway.
>>

most often you will find it under 多順 (most posts), or directly under http://may.2chan.net/b/futaba.php?mode=cat&sort=3

Anonymous
07/15/15(Wed)20:06:50 No.128138622

>>128138694 >>128139691
File: 1414335953624.jpg (164 KB, 395x542)
164 KB JPG
>>128138387
With magnetic tiles, you'd have problems with them either sticking together or flying apart. Poles attracting and repelling etc.; dora indicator flip would be tricky.
With a magnetic table and metal tiles, you'd have problems building the wall. It would be hard to make the table strong enough to hold the top row, but weak enough to release the bottom row.
>>

Shingeki no kyojin/Snk 07/16/15(Thu)09:58:41 No.128163299
File: canon.png (957 KB, 1191x670)
957 KB PNG
Shingeki no kyojin/Snk Anonymous 07/17/15(Fri)01:58:41 No.128163299   [Reply]▶
Movie spoilers from yesterday.

In a post-apocalyptic future where only a fraction of humanity has survived to live humbly amongst the rubble, Eren Jaeger dreams of more. His brainy friend Armin tells tall tales about deserts and oceans beyond the massive walls that guard their civilization, and his girlfriend Mikasa is equally entranced by the birds that soar over those untouchable barricades. Unfortunately, Eren's wish to see the walls opened to the outside world comes at a devastating cost. Enormous humanoid monsters called "Titans" come stampeding through the walls and immediately start eating every man, woman, and child they can find.

In the aftermath of the tragedy, Eren joins the newly minted "Titan Survey Corps" alongside hundreds of other young adults. Some of these new soldiers are hungry for revenge, but most are just plain hungry due to the ensuing famine. While facing down his demons and fighting through past trauma, Eren will have to rediscover what "freedom" means to him in a new world ruled by fear.
>Eren and Mikasa were dating before the first attack
>Mikasa gets separated from Eren and Armin and is presumed dead
>It's implied that Shikishima saved Mikasa's life
>During Eren and Mikasa's reunion Mikasa is butthurt towards Eren since she thinks that he abandoned her after the first attack
>It becomes evident that Shikishima holds romantic feelings for Mikasa
>Armin and Sasha seem to have a thing going on
>Eren and Mikasa's relationship starts out as cold after their reunion but Mikasa slowly starts warming up to him
>At the end of the movie Eren gets eaten and he shifts, Mikasa is the one who pulls him out of his titan form and she hugs him tightly
